page.title: 05Fishing in St Combs (2)
page.content: The{railway}was used to transport men and{nets}to the{larger ports, otherwise the fishermen would have had to move away. The{railway}also enabled a{shellfish fishery to flourish in{St Combs. {Shellfish}from{St Combs}were taken to {Fraserburgh}on the{10.30am train}and were in{Billingsgate market}in{London by the morning.100 years ago the whole village depended upon fishing,there were{142}boats and{215}fishermen. {Herring}fishing was the most important,but{large sailing boats}were used instead of{steam}drifters.White fishing was also important,using long lines from small sailing boats working from the shore at{St Combs.About 200 years ago small sailing boats were able to catch{Cod and Haddock}only a few miles from{St.Combs.}There was no {Herring}fishing at this time.
